front: What is the main benefit of applying Project Schedule Management?
What does a schedule model represent in project management?
What is the output when scheduling data is processed using a scheduling method and tool?
Why is project scheduling important for stakeholder communication?
What type of planning accommodates new knowledge and change during the project?
{{c1::Critical path method}} is a scheduling technique used to determine the longest path.
What type of scheduling is based on adaptive life cycles and product backlogs?
{{c1::On-demand scheduling}} pulls tasks as resources become available.
What is the primary goal of on-demand scheduling in Kanban systems?
In adaptive planning, why might a project plan need to change?
What does a flexible schedule model allow a project team to accommodate?
What project role stays consistent across predictive and adaptive methodologies?
What is the purpose of the Plan Schedule Management process?
back: To define how the schedule will be managed

front: What is the key output of the Plan Schedule Management process?
{{c1::Alternatives analysis}} is used to determine the best scheduling methodology or level of detail.
{{c1::Expert judgment}} is used in the Plan Schedule Management process to leverage specialized knowledge.
What does the schedule management plan define regarding performance thresholds?
What type of project information includes staff hours or cubic yards?
The {{c1::schedule management plan}} may define rules for earned value techniques such as SPI and SV.
What input influences summary schedule milestones and is a source for the Plan Schedule Management process?
{{c1::Rolling wave planning}} is an iterative planning technique in which near-term work is planned in detail and future work at a higher level.
What does the activity list include?
{{c1::Activity attributes}} extend the description of activities by including components such as IDs, relationships, and constraints.
What is the purpose of activity attributes?
back: To describe components related to an activity

front: {{c1::Milestone list}} identifies significant events and indicates if they are mandatory or optional.
How long is a milestone's duration in a schedule?
{{c1::Finish-to-start (FS)}} means the successor cannot start until the predecessor finishes.
{{c1::Finish-to-finish (FF)}} means the successor cannot finish until the predecessor finishes.
{{c1::Start-to-start (SS)}} means the successor cannot start until the predecessor starts.
{{c1::Start-to-finish (SF)}} means the successor cannot finish until the predecessor starts.
Editing cannot finish until writing finishes. What relationship is this?
Pouring concrete and leveling must start at the same time. What relationship is this?
You cannot shut down the old system until the new one starts. What relationship is this?
{{c1::Mandatory dependencies}} are legally or contractually required, or inherent to the work.
{{c1::Discretionary dependencies}} are based on best practices or specific project decisions.
{{c1::External dependencies}} are outside the project team's control.
{{c1::Internal dependencies}} are within the control of the project team.
A {{c1::lead}} is the amount of time a successor activity can be advanced with respect to a predecessor activity.
A {{c1::lag}} is the amount of time a successor activity will be delayed with respect to a predecessor activity.
Landscaping scheduled task starts 2 weeks before the punch list  is complete. What is this an example of?
Editing scheduled task starts 15 days after writing scheduled task starts. What is this an example of?
What is the purpose of the Sequence Activities process in project schedule management?
What is the key benefit of the Sequence Activities process?
What output visually represents logical relationships between project activities?
{{c1::Project schedule network diagrams}} are used to depict logical relationships among project activities.
{{c1::Path convergence}} occurs when an activity has multiple predecessor activities.
{{c1::Path divergence}} occurs when an activity has multiple successor activities.
Which technique uses historical data from similar projects to estimate duration?
Which estimating technique multiplies units of work by time per unit?
What is the three-point estimating formula using triangular distribution?
What estimating technique involves decomposing work into detailed components?
What does reserve analysis determine in duration estimating?
What law describes how work expands to fill available time?
{{c1::Duration estimates}} are quantitative assessments of the likely number of time periods that are required to complete an activity, a phase, or a project.
{{c1::Bottom-up estimating}} is a method of estimating project duration or cost by aggregating the estimates of the lowerlevel components of the WBS.
{{c1::Triangular distribution}} is used when there is insufficient historical data or when using judgmental data.
{{c1::Develop Schedule}} is the process of analyzing activity sequences, durations, resource requirements, and constraints to create a schedule model.
{{c1::Critical path method}} estimates the minimum project duration and determines schedule flexibility.
What does the critical path determine?
{{c1::Resource leveling}} adjusts start/finish dates based on resource constraints and may change the critical path.
{{c1::Resource smoothing}} adjusts activities so resources don't exceed limits without changing the critical path.
{{c1::What-if scenario analysis}} evaluates scenarios to predict impact on project objectives.
{{c1::Simulation}} uses risks and uncertainties to calculate schedule outcomes, often using Monte Carlo analysis.
{{c1::Crashing}} adds resources to shorten schedule duration at least cost increase.
{{c1::Fast tracking}} performs activities in parallel to reduce duration but may increase risk.
{{c1::Schedule baseline}} is the approved schedule version used to compare against actual results.
{{c1::Bar charts}} show activities and durations graphically on a time scale.
{{c1::Project calendars}} identify working days and shifts for scheduled activities.
{{c1::PMIS}} includes scheduling software to generate dates from activity and resource data.
{{c1::What-if scenario}} analysis is the process of evaluating scenarios in order to predict their effect, positive or negative, on project objectives.
{{c1::Simulation}} models the combined effects of individual project risks and other sources of uncertainty to evaluate their potential impact on achieving project objectives.
The most common simulation technique is {{c1::Monte Carlo analysis}}, in which risks and other sources of uncertainty are used to calculate possible schedule outcomes for the total project.
What is the minimum information included in a project schedule?
back: Planned start and finish dates for each activity.

front: {{c1::Earned value analysis}} assesses schedule performance using SV and SPI.
{{c1::Iteration burndown chart}} tracks remaining work against ideal and forecast lines.
{{c1::Performance reviews}} compare actual vs. planned start, finish, and progress.
{{c1::Trend analysis}} is used to evaluate project performance over time.
{{c1::Variance analysis}} compares planned vs. actual start/finish dates and durations.
{{c1::Work performance information}} reflects project performance vs. the schedule baseline.
{{c1::Schedule forecasts}} predict future schedule performance using current data.
What plan provides criteria for developing and controlling the schedule?
